projects.title_en: Struve H function for Boost.math
Type inference in EO programming language
projects.annotation: We need to build a type inference subsystem for the EO compiler that can determine object types at compile time without relying on explicit type annotations. EO is an untyped object-oriented language. We need to design a method‚Äîand build a tool‚Äîthat can "guess" the types of objects (which we call formas) with high precision.
projects.goals: Create type inference module for EO compiler
projects.tasks: EO is an untyped language: https://www.eolang.org. We need to design a method‚Äîand build a tool‚Äîthat can "guess" the types of objects (which we call formas) with high precision. Similar systems already exist, such as pytype (https://github.com/google/pytype) for Python and flow (https://github.com/facebook/flow) JavaScript. The tool must be written in Java.
projects.requirements: A student must already be proficient in Java or C++, fluent in written English, able to work remotely without direct supervision, and have a GitHub account. To join the project, the student must submit at least three pull requests to one of our open-source GitHub projects to demonstrate coding ability and discipline.

projects.title_en: AOT algorithmization of objects in EO language
projects.annotation: EO is a pure object-oriented language, where every number and arithmetic operation is an object. We aim to develop a method and tool that can translate composite objects into procedural algorithms in a language like Rust.
projects.goals: Build an AOT tool that converts objects to procedures
projects.tasks: We aim to develop a method and tool that can translate composite objects into procedural algorithms in a language like Rust.
projects.requirements: A student must already be proficient in Java or C++, fluent in written English, able to work remotely without direct supervision, and have a GitHub account. To join the project, the student must submit at least three pull requests to one of our open-source GitHub projects to demonstrate coding ability and discipline.

projects.title_en: Dataflow graph evaluation virtual machine
projects.annotation: Any EO object can be represented as a graph. We already have a tool (https://github.com/objectionary/sodg-maven-plugin) that converts EO programs into graphs. The next step is to build a graph-based dataflow virtual machine that can dataize (evaluate) these objects, in Rust.
projects.goals: Build a virtual machine for EO programs
projects.tasks: 1) Build a virtual machine; 2) Write tests.
projects.requirements: A student must already be proficient in Java or C++, fluent in written English, able to work remotely without direct supervision, and have a GitHub account. To join the project, the student must submit at least three pull requests to one of our open-source GitHub projects to demonstrate coding ability and discipline.

projects.title_en: Interactive code inspector for EO programs
projects.annotation: EO is a compiled object-oriented programming language. We need to create a runtime debugger/inspector for it. The backend of the inspector must be written in Java, while its front-end in JavaScript. We've started implementing this feature earlier, but didn't manage to finish so far: objectionary/eoc#500.
projects.requirements: A student must already be proficient in Java or C++, fluent in written English, able to work remotely without direct supervision, and have a GitHub account. To join the project, the student must submit at least three pull requests to one of our open-source GitHub projects to demonstrate coding ability and discipline.

projects.title_en: IntelliJ plugin for EO language
projects.annotation: A few years ago, we've created an EO plugin for IntelliJ IDEA. It highlights the syntax of EO and helps detect syntax errors. However, its functionality is pretty limited: it doesn't support code completion, compilation, debugging, and many other features a user would expect. It would be nice to improve the plugin and release an updated version with all the needed features.
projects.goals: Release working version of EO plugin
projects.tasks: Release a new version of the plugin
projects.requirements: A student must already be proficient in Java or C++, fluent in written English, able to work remotely without direct supervision, and have a GitHub account. To join the project, the student must submit at least three pull requests to one of our open-source GitHub projects to demonstrate coding ability and discipline.

projects.title_en: Lean4-based proof of confluence for ùúë-calculus
projects.annotation: EOLANG (https://github.com/objectionary/eo) is based on ùúë-calculus ‚Äî a formalism we use to specify object semantics. We believe that ùúë-calculus is confluent. This means that when applying reduction rules to terms, the order in which reductions are applied does not affect the final result. It also implies that if there are two distinct reductions or sequences of reductions applicable to the same term, there exists a term reachable from both results by applying (possibly empty) sequences of additional reductions. This has not been formally proven; it is simply what we believe to be true about ùúë-calculus. We attempted to prove the confluence property (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confluence_(abstract_rewriting)) of ùúë-calculus using Lean4, but the work (https://github.com/objectionary/proof) remains unfinished.
projects.requirements: A student must already be proficient in Java or C++, fluent in written English, able to work remotely without direct supervision, and have a GitHub account. To join the project, the student must submit at least three pull requests to one of our open-source GitHub projects to demonstrate coding ability and discipline.

Autocompletion with multi-line edits, cross-file suggestions, and context-aware code completions
projects.annotation:
We want to develop a technology for training and fine-tuning a neural model to enable next edit action prediction feature in IDE. The key difference from regular auto-completion is that next edit action prediction allows to predict not only the chunk of code to insert but a cursor position. Moreover, the cursors position may be located at any file in the project.


Technical Challenges :

1. Training data. How to prepare self-supervised training data of user‚Äôs edits from existing code base history;
2. Fast enough to be run on user‚Äôs computer. The next edit prediction should take no more than 250ms for better user experience;
3. Compute efficient fine-tuning. There is an algorithm that allows to fine-tune the basic model and make it personal for the specific user. The fine-tuning can be run at the background on a local computer of the user


To be concise we want to have similar feature as Cursor IDE has 

https://docs.cursor.com/en/tab/overview

Private Blockchain‚ÄìEnabled Computer Vision for Product Authentication and Tracking
projects.annotation:
Private blockchain technology offers a tamper-resistant transaction log with built-in auditing mechanisms. In complex modern supply chains involving thousands of manufacturers and carriers, it can significantly improve trust, transparency, and organization among participants. However, the peer-to-peer nature of blockchain networks introduces important performance considerations.

 Another critical aspect is the use of nano-lens technology or basic camera prototypes to detect and analyze physical product patterns. For instance, in a museum, nano-lenses could examine brushstroke patterns to understand how a painting was created, and this information could then be stored securely on the blockchain in an abstracted form. In industrial automation, similar systems could capture data such as screw-tightening angles or monitor paint fading on products.

 This paper proposes a smart-contract-based framework for supply chain management that integrates private blockchain with computer vision technology, IoT devices, security policies, and hardware-based cryptographic key management. By analyzing physical product attributes‚Äîsuch as manufacturing patterns or signs of wear‚Äîvia computer vision and recording them on the blockchain, the system streamlines interactions, enhances security and efficiency, minimizes manual key handling, and enables precise, real-time tracking throughout the supply chain.


 –ß–∞—Å—Ç–Ω—ã–π –±–ª–æ–∫—á–µ–π–Ω –ø—Ä–µ–¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç –Ω–∞–¥–µ–∂–Ω—ã–π –∏ –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–π –∂—É—Ä–Ω–∞–ª —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–∑–∞–∫—Ü–∏–π —Å –≤—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–º–∏ –º–µ—Ö–∞–Ω–∏–∑–º–∞–º–∏ –∞—É–¥–∏—Ç–∞. –í —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω—ã—Ö —Å–æ–≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö —Ü–µ–ø–æ—á–∫–∞—Ö –ø–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–æ–∫, –≤–∫–ª—é—á–∞—é—â–∏—Ö —Ç—ã—Å—è—á–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–∏–∑–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª–µ–π –∏ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≤–æ–∑—á–∏–∫–æ–≤, –æ–Ω —Å–ø–æ—Å–æ–±–µ–Ω –∑–Ω–∞—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ –ø–æ–≤—ã—Å–∏—Ç—å –¥–æ–≤–µ—Ä–∏–µ, –ø—Ä–æ–∑—Ä–∞—á–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å –∏ –æ—Ä–≥–∞–Ω–∏–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å –≤–∑–∞–∏–º–æ–¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏—è —É—á–∞—Å—Ç–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤. –û–¥–Ω–∞–∫–æ –æ–¥–Ω–æ—Ä–∞–Ω–≥–æ–≤–∞—è –ø—Ä–∏—Ä–æ–¥–∞ –±–ª–æ–∫—á–µ–π–Ω-—Å–µ—Ç–µ–π –≤–ª–µ—á—ë—Ç –∑–∞ —Å–æ–±–æ–π –≤–∞–∂–Ω—ã–µ –≤–æ–ø—Ä–æ—Å—ã –ø—Ä–æ–∏–∑–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏.

 –î—Ä—É–≥–æ–π –∫–ª—é—á–µ–≤–æ–π –∞—Å–ø–µ–∫—Ç ‚Äî –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–µ –Ω–∞–Ω–æ–ª–∏–Ω–∑ –∏–ª–∏ –±–∞–∑–æ–≤—ã—Ö –∫–∞–º–µ—Ä –¥–ª—è –æ–±–Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏ –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞ —Ñ–∏–∑–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö —Ö–∞—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–∏–∫ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ü–∏–∏. –ù–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, –≤ –º—É–∑–µ–µ –Ω–∞–Ω–æ–ª–∏–Ω–∑—ã –º–æ–≥—É—Ç –∏–∑—É—á–∞—Ç—å –º–∞–∑–∫–∏ –∫–∏—Å—Ç–∏, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –ø–æ–Ω—è—Ç—å, –∫–∞–∫ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–≤–∞–ª–∞—Å—å –∫–∞—Ä—Ç–∏–Ω–∞, –∏ –∑–∞—Ç–µ–º –≤ –∞–±—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–Ω–æ–º –≤–∏–¥–µ —Å–æ—Ö—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—Ç—å —ç—Ç—É –∏–Ω—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü–∏—é –≤ –±–ª–æ–∫—á–µ–π–Ω–µ. –í –ø—Ä–æ–º—ã—à–ª–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–π –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–∏ —Ç–∞–∫–∏–µ —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º—ã –º–æ–≥—É—Ç —Ñ–∏–∫—Å–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å, –ø–æ–¥ –∫–∞–∫–∏–º–∏ —É–≥–ª–∞–º–∏ –∑–∞–∫—Ä—É—á–µ–Ω—ã –≤–∏–Ω—Ç—ã, –∏–ª–∏ –æ—Ç—Å–ª–µ–∂–∏–≤–∞—Ç—å –≤—ã—Ü–≤–µ—Ç–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∫–∏ –Ω–∞ –∏–∑–¥–µ–ª–∏—è—Ö.

 –í –¥–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–µ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ª–∞–≥–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è —Å–º–∞—Ä—Ç-–∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–Ω–∞—è –ø–ª–∞—Ç—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞ –¥–ª—è —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è —Ü–µ–ø–æ—á–∫–∞–º–∏ –ø–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–æ–∫, –æ–±—ä–µ–¥–∏–Ω—è—é—â–∞—è —á–∞—Å—Ç–Ω—ã–π –±–ª–æ–∫—á–µ–π–Ω, —Ç–µ—Ö–Ω–æ–ª–æ–≥–∏–∏ –∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∑—Ä–µ–Ω–∏—è, —É—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç–∞ –≤–µ—â–µ–π, –ø–æ–ª–∏—Ç–∏–∫–∏ –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∏ –∞–ø–ø–∞—Ä–∞—Ç–Ω—ã–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è –¥–ª—è —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è –∫—Ä–∏–ø—Ç–æ–≥—Ä–∞—Ñ–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–º–∏ –∫–ª—é—á–∞–º–∏. –ê–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ —Ñ–∏–∑–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö —Ö–∞—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–∏–∫ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ü–∏–∏ —Å –ø–æ–º–æ—â—å—é –∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∑—Ä–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏ –∏—Ö –∑–∞–ø–∏—Å—å –≤ –±–ª–æ–∫—á–µ–π–Ω —É–ø—Ä–æ—â–∞—é—Ç –≤–∑–∞–∏–º–æ–¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏–µ, –ø–æ–≤—ã—à–∞—é—Ç –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å –∏ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å, –º–∏–Ω–∏–º–∏–∑–∏—Ä—É—é—Ç —Ä—É—á–Ω–æ–µ —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ –∫–ª—é—á–∞–º–∏ –∏ –æ–±–µ—Å–ø–µ—á–∏–≤–∞—é—Ç —Ç–æ—á–Ω–æ–µ –æ—Ç—Å–ª–µ–∂–∏–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ü–∏–∏ –≤ —Ä–µ–∂–∏–º–µ —Ä–µ–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–∏ –Ω–∞ –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ç–∞–ø–∞—Ö —Ü–µ–ø–æ—á–∫–∏ –ø–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–æ–∫.

projects.title_en: Knowledge distillation between LLMs and structured-data models for event sequence modeling
Simulation of signals in cyclic neural networks for representation of cognitive functions and elements of consciousness

GFlowNet Fine-Tuning of LLMs for Prompt-Conditioned SMILES Generation
projects.annotation: Large language models (LLMs) trained on molecular strings such as SMILES or SELFIES can produce chemically valid candidates under textual constraints (prompts), but standard fine-tuning and reinforcement learning approaches tend to optimize for a single high-reward solution, sacrificing coverage of diverse modes. This project proposes to fine-tune an LLM with a GFlowNet objective so that the model samples molecules from a distribution proportional to R(m | c) conditioned on a prompt c, where R aggregates property targets and constraints. Following the idea of Hu et al. (2024) (https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04363) , the LLM serves as the forward policy and is trained with Sub-Trajectory Balance to amortize intractable conditional inference. The key expected advantages are (i) set-level diversity (mode coverage), (ii) robustness to misspecified or noisy proxy rewards, and (iii) amortized sampling for arbitrary text conditions.

 3) –†–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –¥–æ–æ–±—É—á–µ–Ω–∏–µ LLM —Å GFlowNet –¥–ª—è prompt-conditioned –≥–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏ SMILES.
 4) –°—Ä–∞–≤–Ω–∏—Ç—å –ø–æ–ª—É—á–µ–Ω–Ω—É—é –º–æ–¥–µ–ª—å —Å –æ–±—ã—á–Ω—ã–º fine-tuning –∏ RL –ø–æ –º–µ—Ç—Ä–∏–∫–∞–º —Ä–∞–∑–Ω–æ–æ–±—Ä–∞–∑–∏—è –∏ –∫–∞—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –º–æ–ª–µ–∫—É–ª.
 5) –û—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∏—Ç—å —Ä–µ–∑—É–ª—å—Ç–∞—Ç—ã –∏ —Ä–µ–∫–æ–º–µ–Ω–¥–∞—Ü–∏–∏ –¥–ª—è –¥–∞–ª—å–Ω–µ–π—à–µ–≥–æ —Ä–∞–∑–≤–∏—Ç–∏—è –ø–æ–¥—Ö–æ–¥–∞.

 –í —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–µ [3] –±—ã–ª–∞ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ª–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∞ –æ–±—â–∞—è –≤–µ—Ä–æ—è—Ç–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä–∞ –¥–ª—è –æ—Ü–µ–Ω–æ–∫ —Ç–∏–ø–∞ –ë–µ—Ä—Ä–∏‚Äì–≠—Å—Å–µ–µ–Ω–∞ —Å –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä–∞–º–∏ –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è –∫ SGD. –í [4] —ç—Ç–∏ –º–µ—Ç–æ–¥—ã –±—ã–ª–∏ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –¥–ª—è –ø–æ–ª—É—á–µ–Ω–∏—è —Å–∫–æ—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–µ–π —Å—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –≤ –¶–ü–¢ –¥–ª—è —Å—Ç–æ—Ö–∞—Å—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –≥—Ä–∞–¥–∏–µ–Ω—Ç–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Å–ø—É—Å–∫–∞ (SGD), —Ä–∞–∑–≤–∏–≤–∞—è —Ä–µ–∑—É–ª—å—Ç–∞—Ç—ã [3]. –¶–µ–ª—å –¥–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–∞ —Å–æ—Å—Ç–æ–∏—Ç –≤ –∏–∑—É—á–µ–Ω–∏–∏ —ç—Ç–∏—Ö —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç –∏ –∞–¥–∞–ø—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–∏ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ª–æ–∂–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –º–µ—Ç–æ–¥–æ–≤ –∫ –∞–ª–≥–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–º—É SEG.

Improved optimization of LogSumExp and its applications in ML
projects.annotation: The LogSumExp function plays a central role in many important optimization problems from machine learning, optimal transport, distributionally robust optimization and other applications. When the number of exponential terms inside the logarithm is large or infinite, existing optimization approaches suffer from numerical instabilities and other issues. Recently, a new approach to optimizing LogSumExp has been proposed, see https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.24894. The project consist in choosing an application area and comparing the approach to the baseline. For more details, see the project description in https://disk.yandex.ru/i/xcIDF79xM3MRPg.
projects.goals: Compare the new approach to LogSumExp optimization with existing methods in a chosen area.
projects.requirements: –°onfident Python skills (experience with PyTorch is preferable), solid knowledge of convex optimization.

projects.title_en: Simulation of attacks on software-defined networks
projects.annotation:
–í —Å–≤—è–∑–∏ —Å —Å—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–º —Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ–º —á–∏—Å–ª–∞ –∫–æ—Ä–ø–æ—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ã—Ö —Å–µ—Ç–µ–π, –≤ —Ç–æ–º —á–∏—Å–ª–µ —Ç–µ–ª–µ–∫–æ–º–º—É–Ω–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö —Å–µ—Ç–µ–π –¥–∞—Ç–∞-—Ü–µ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–≤, –≤–æ–∑–Ω–∏–∫–ª–∞ –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º–∞ —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏–º–∏. –ë—ã–ª–∞ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ª–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∞ –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–∞ SDN (Software-Defined Network). SDN –æ–±–µ—Å–ø–µ—á–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ —Å–µ—Ç–µ–≤–æ–π –≤–∏—Ä—Ç—É–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–∏, —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª—è–µ—Ç –ø–ª–æ—Å–∫–æ—Å—Ç–∏ —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏ –∫–æ–º–º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–∏, —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑—É–µ—Ç –ª–æ–≥–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏ —Ü–µ–Ω—Ç—Ä–∞–ª–∏–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–µ —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ –∏ –æ—Ç–∫—Ä—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –≥–∏–±–∫–æ–≥–æ –∫–æ–Ω—Ñ–∏–≥—É—Ä–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è —Å–µ—Ç–∏ –≤ —Å–æ–æ—Ç–≤–µ—Ç—Å—Ç–≤–∏–∏ —Å –ø–æ—Ç—Ä–µ–±–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—è–º–∏ —Å–µ—Ä–≤–∏—Å–æ–≤. –ü–æ—Å–∫–æ–ª—å–∫—É –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–∞ SDN –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ø–æ–ª–∞–≥–∞–µ—Ç —Å–æ–≤–µ—Ä—à–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –∏–Ω–æ–π –ø–æ–¥—Ö–æ–¥ –∫ —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–∏ —Å–µ—Ç–µ–≤–æ–π –∏–Ω—Ñ—Ä–∞—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä—ã, –æ–Ω–∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –ø—Ä–∏–≤–Ω–æ—Å–∏—Ç –Ω–æ–≤—ã–µ –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—ã –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏. –ü–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∑–ª–æ–Ω–∞–º–µ—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –≤–æ–∑–¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏—è –Ω–∞ SDN –ø–æ–∑–≤–æ–ª–∏—Ç —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞—Ç—å –º–µ—Ç–æ–¥—ã –æ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è –∞—Ç–∞–∫, –∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –º–µ—Ç–æ–¥—ã –¥–ª—è –∏—Ö –ø—Ä–µ–¥–æ—Ç–≤—Ä–∞—â–µ–Ω–∏—è. 
 –í —Ä–∞–º–∫–∞—Ö —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—ã –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ª–∞–≥–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –º–æ–¥–µ–ª—å –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–Ω–æ-–∫–æ–Ω—Ñ–∏–≥—É—Ä–∏—Ä—É–µ–º–æ–π —Å–µ—Ç–∏ (SDN) –∏ —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞—Ç—å –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω—ã–µ —Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä–∏–∏ –∞—Ç–∞–∫ –Ω–∞ SDN. –ß–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π —ç–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω—Ç –ø–æ –∏–º–∏—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω–æ–º—É –º–æ–¥–µ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—é –∞—Ç–∞–∫ –Ω–∞ SDN –º–æ–∂–µ—Ç –ø—Ä–æ–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å—Å—è –≤ –æ–±–ª–∞–∫–µ/–Ω–∞ –≥—Ä–∏–¥-—Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–µ/–Ω–∞ –∫–ª–∞—Å—Ç–µ—Ä–µ.

Deep Learning in Finance: Deep Momentum
projects.annotation:
We are the Quantitative Investment Strategies team and we are happy to introduce the student projects / theses this year. The aim of our projects is to introduce people to quantitative approach for the investment strategies creation, which includes the combination of applied statistical learning techniques and financial knowledge for strategies engineering. The proposed projects are especially representative of the actual tasks that a quantitative analyst / data scientist solves in line of their job activities on largest investment firms and hedge funds across the globe. Moreover, the proposed
 projects not only allow to explore applied quantitative finance in practice, but also produce novel financial machine learning academic research.

 Additionally, the results of the projects may serve as a strong point for full-time
 internship in our team with the potential to convert the research into the real-life
 strategy / product that our clients will be able to use. Furthermore, the outstandingly performing students might be offered a full-time position in our team after the projects are completed.

 What we offer:
 ‚Ä¢ Supervision on bi-weekly basis with deep involvement into the research and
 implementation issues and the practitioners perspective on the financial ML tasks
 ‚Ä¢ Ready-to-use backtesting infrastructure with pre-cleaned data and access to multiple alternative data sources, such that the students may focus solely on the statistical learning / feature engineering
 ‚Ä¢ Topics that are on the edge of applied financial machine learning research with novel approaches
 ‚Ä¢ Freedom for students in the research pipeline and ideas to test, subject to approval from the supervisors

 Project 1 ‚Äî Deep Learning in Finance. Deep Momentum.
 The financial machine learning sphere has been expanding recently into the asset pricing literature via brand new solely data science-driven strategies. However, as practice shows, these strategies rarely work out-of-sample and usually lack basic financial intuition to inject ML at the strategy parameters, such that those actually enhance existing approaches. We aim to construct the neural network not to solve return prediction task, but to optimally combine the existing and well-known financial phenomena (Momentum) into the optimal portfolio.
projects.goals: We aim to construct the neural network not to solve return prediction task, but to optimally combine the existing and well-known financial phenomena (Momentum) into the optimal portfolio.
projects.tasks:
1. Create Momentum portfolios.
 2. Engineer a Volatility-Managed baseline [Barosso & Santa-Clara, 2015].
 3. Introduce a Feedforward NN to optimally combine the strategies.
 4. (Bonus): Implement -LSTM for Volatility-Managed strategy modification.
 5. (Bonus): Study and produce a custom Transformer architecture for Enhanced
 Momentum [Zohren et al., 2019].
 6. (Bonus): Research own finance-motivated architecture.
projects.requirements:
- Deep Learning academic skills: be "fluent" in custom architectures and implementation (preferably in PyTorch)
 - Data Science skills in feature preprocessing / statistical testing for feature selection
 - Knowledge of financial markets is a plus, but not required at all

projects.title_en: Quantitative Finance: Enhanced Momentum
projects.annotation:
We are the Quantitative Investment Strategies team and we are happy to introduce the student projects / theses this year. The aim of our projects is to introduce people to quantitative approach for the investment strategies creation, which includes the combination of applied statistical learning techniques and financial knowledge for strategies engineering. The proposed projects are especially representative of the actual tasks that a quantitative analyst / data scientist solves in line of their job activities on largest investment firms and hedge funds across the globe. Moreover, the proposed
 projects not only allow to explore applied quantitative finance in practice, but also produce novel financial machine learning academic research.

 Additionally, the results of the projects may serve as a strong point for full-time
 internship in our team with the potential to convert the research into the real-life
 strategy / product that our clients will be able to use. Furthermore, the outstandingly performing students might be offered a full-time position in our team after the projects are completed.

 Project 2 ‚Äî Quantitative Finance. Enhanced Momentum.
 Momentum strategies have been one of the most well-known and well-studied
 phenomenon in finance, which is still surprisingly relevant for investors that aim to harvest risk premia. While this factor has been robust over time, there have been multiple studies that claim the Momentum being a premium for crashes / left-tail exposure [Chabi-Yo et al., 2018; Ruenzi and Weigert, 2018]. Moreover, the Momentum implementation in practice usually faces severe discrepancies from academic research: no-shorting constraint and transaction costs being one of the most impactful. We offer a project to explore multiple modifications of Momentum that try to mitigate these market frictions.
projects.goals: We offer a project to explore multiple modifications of Momentum that try to mitigate these market frictions.
projects.tasks:
1. Create Momentum portfolios.
 2. Engineer a Volatility-Managed baseline [Barosso & Santa-Clara, 2015].
 3. Introduce a left-tail risk premium harvesting [Chabi-Yo et al., 2018; Ruenzi and Weigert, 2018].
 4. Implement a Systematic Momentum [Li, Yuan, Zhou, 2022].
 5. (Bonus): Produce a pipeline for the tracking error-based cross-validation for
 transaction costs.
 6. (Bonus): Find a strategy (e.g., an academic paper) that robustly outperforms
 Fractional Momentum in out-of-sample setting.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge of quantitative finance (factor models, strategies backtesting)
 - Statistical Learning skills (testing for statistical significance, design of statistical estimators)
 - Python (pandas, polars, scikit-learn, statsmodels, scipy)

projects.title_en: Factor Model for PnL Explainer: Macroeconomic Factors with XAI.
projects.annotation:
We are the Quantitative Investment Strategies team and we are happy to introduce the student projects / theses this year. The aim of our projects is to introduce people to quantitative approach for the investment strategies creation, which includes the combination of applied statistical learning techniques and financial knowledge for strategies engineering. The proposed projects are especially representative of the actual tasks that a quantitative analyst / data scientist solves in line of their job activities on largest investment firms and hedge funds across the globe. Moreover, the proposed
 projects not only allow to explore applied quantitative finance in practice, but also produce novel financial machine learning academic research.

 Additionally, the results of the projects may serve as a strong point for full-time
 internship in our team with the potential to convert the research into the real-life
 strategy / product that our clients will be able to use. Furthermore, the outstandingly performing students might be offered a full-time position in our team after the projects are completed.

 Project 3 ‚Äî Factor Model for PnL Explainer. Macroeconomic Explainable Factors / XAI.
 The asset manager‚Äôs job consists not only of strategies creation and implementation, but also is built upon the client-based risk decomposition that leads to tailored portfolios.
 One of such tailor-made approaches is portfolio performance explanation with
 statistical learning methods. The aim of this project is to enhance the regression model that underlies the PnL Explainer service for the clients with feature engineering and / or robust L1-sparsity based feature selection.
projects.goals: The aim of this project is to enhance the regression model that underlies the PnL Explainer service for the clients with feature engineering and / or robust L1-sparsity based feature selection.
projects.tasks:
1. Implement a testing pipeline for features, aimed for Russian stocks inference model.
 2. Suggest a robust statistical inference framework for feature selection in linear setting (e.g., Stability Selection [Meinshausen & B√ºhlmann, 2010]).
 3. Search for new data sources / feature ideas that we would help to implement for the model.
 4. (Bonus): Introduce a methodology for mapping the existing Equity Factors into macroeconomic features that are easy for clients to understand.
 5. (Bonus): Implement a non-linear feature transformations with XAI techniques to assess the features and their economic meaning.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge of feature engineering techniques and willingness to be self-driven in generating feature engineering hypotheses
 - Statistical Learning Theory (design of estimators, feature selection, regularized linear models)
 - Bonus: XAI knowledge and willingness to implement non-linear models

projects.title_en: Survey on Metacomplexity and its Connections to Complexity Theory and Cryptography
projects.annotation:
Metacomplexity is an emerging field at the intersection of complexity theory, cryptography, and algorithmic information theory. Broadly, it studies the complexity of computing complexity measures themselves‚Äîfor example, problems such as deciding whether a string has low Kolmogorov complexity under various resource bounds. These questions have turned out to be deeply connected to some of the most fundamental open problems in complexity theory and cryptography.

 Many recent works have revealed interesting duality theorems: the existence of cryptographic one-way functions is equivalent to the average-case hardness of certain Kolmogorov complexity problems, to the failure of time-bounded symmetry of information, and to the hardness of several other problems involving Kolmogorov complexity.

 Because of these developments, metacomplexity has become a central theme in modern complexity theory. The goal of the project is to produce a detailed survey of the main results, techniques, connections, and open problems in metacomplexity.

 Details: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1HNz8Wjq38EgA9MIImFQP2p1vwHDaL8rz/view?usp=sharing
projects.goals: The goal of the project is to produce a detailed survey of the main results, techniques, connections, and open problems in metacomplexity.
projects.tasks: To produce a detailed survey of the field of metacomplexity, the focus will be on the main results and central quantities and problems in metacomplexity (such as Kt, pKt, rKt, MKtP, and McKTP), their interconnections and relationships with cryptography and complexity assumptions, the core tools and proof techniques used in the area, and the most important directions for future work. If time and interest allow, the project may also expand to exploring specific open questions in the field.
projects.requirements: Strong interest in theoretical computer science. Background in computational complexity.

projects.title_en: Learning-Theoretic Characterizations of Finite- State and Resource-Bounded Dimensions
projects.annotation:
The interaction between algorithmic dimensions and learning theory has recently been advanced by Lutz and Migunov, who characterized classical algorithmic dimensions in terms of the inability of certain learning functions to detect patterns in infinite sequences. 

 Finite-state dimension, introduced as the finite-state analogue of Hausdorff and algorithmic dimension, captures the asymptotic density of information measured using by finite-state automata. Finite-state dimension is a robust mathematical concept with equivalent definitions in terms of finite-state compressors, predictors, and block entropy rates.

 An open question is whether finite-state dimension also admits a learning theory characterization. Such a characterization would unify two important viewpoints (automata-based compression and algorithmic learning) and provide new techniques for analyzing randomness and compressibility. Beyond finite-state dimension, similar approaches may lead to learning-theoretic characterizations of resource-bounded dimensions (e.g., polynomial-time and PSPACE dimension).

 Details: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1BnY2Me1QdJ7x8UvGYB_Z05IMzPjnD9f4/view?usp=sharing
projects.goals: To develop a learning-theoretic characterization of finite-state and resource-bounded dimensions, inspired by the Lutz‚ÄìMigunov framework.
projects.tasks:
Study foundational literature on finite-state dimension (compressibility, entropy, automata-theoretic definitions). Read and understand the characterization of algorithmic dimensions via learning functions by Lutz and Migunov.

 Explore a learning theoretic formulation of finite-state dimension. If possible, extend methods to resource-bounded dimensions (PTIME, PSPACE).
projects.requirements: Strong interest in theoretical computer science. Background in theory of computation and learning theory is desirable.

projects.title_en: Normality Dimension Thesis and the Davenport‚ÄìErd√∂s Theorem
projects.annotation:
Finite-state dimension measures the rate of information in an infinite sequence as detected by finite-state automata. Normal numbers (numbers whose base-b expansion has every finite block of digits occurring with the expected limiting frequency) are precisely those real numbers whose base expansions have finite-state dimension equal to 1.

 The Normality Dimension Thesis (Lutz, 2005) proposes that every classical theorem about Borel normality is the dimension-1 special case of a more general theorem about finite-state dimension. This thesis has been verified in several cases, where results on normal numbers have been successfully extended to more general theorems concerning finite-state dimension.

 The Davenport‚ÄìErd√∂s theorem (1952) established that if p(x) is a non-constant integer-valued polynomial, then the concatenation 0.p(1)p(2)p(3)... is normal. Since normality coincides with finite-state dimension 1, a natural open problem is whether the Davenport‚ÄìErd√∂s theorem can be seen as the dimension-1 instance of a more general theorem about finite-state dimension, thereby verifying the Normality Dimension Thesis in this context.

 Recent work by Clanin and Rayman (2025) made significant progress toward this goal by analyzing the finite-state dimension of Copeland‚ÄìErd√∂s sequences and their transformations under polynomials. However, whether the thesis holds in case of the Davenport-Erd√∂s theorem still remains open. 

 Details: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1GcOlwln873G0i8MIHMja5YgS76y-qAuz/view?usp=sharing
projects.goals: To investigate the Normality Dimension Thesis by first studying and attempting verifications in related results where the thesis remains open, and then addressing the Davenport‚ÄìErd√∂s theorem itself.
projects.tasks:
Study the theory of normal numbers and finite-state dimension. Read and understand recent work on finite-state dimension and polynomial transformations (including the paper by Clanin and Rayman).

 Verify the Normality Dimension Thesis for selected related results. Progress to investigating the thesis in the setting of the Davenport‚ÄìErd√∂s theorem.
projects.requirements: Strong interest in theoretical computer science and mathematics.

projects.title_en: Discrepancy Estimates for Continued Fraction Normal Numbers
projects.annotation:
A real number is called normal (to base b) if, in its base-b expansion, every finite block of digits appears with the correct limiting frequency. For example, the Champernowne number 0.123456789101112‚Ä¶, obtained by concatenating all positive integers in base 10, is normal in base 10. Normality is a central concept in number theory, probability, and theoretical computer science.

 A number is Continued Fraction normal if every finite block of digits appears with the frequency prescribed by the Gauss measure in its continued fraction expansion. Almost all real numbers are CF-normal, but producing explicit examples is not easy. Adler‚ÄìKeane‚ÄìSmorodinsky constructed a Champernowne-style CF-normal number by concatenating the continued-fraction expansions of rationals, while Vandehey later gave new constructions and tools for studying CF-normality.

 Beyond establishing normality, one can ask how quickly the frequency of occurrence of every finite block of digits in a number converges to the limiting distribution. This rate is captured by the notion of discrepancy. For Champernowne‚Äôs number, sharp discrepancy bounds are known thanks to Schiffer and a recent work by Becher and Graus. However, in the world of continued fractions, such discrepancy estimates remain largely open.

 This project begins with experimental verification: coding and plotting the discrepancy of the Adler‚ÄìKeane‚ÄìSmorodinsky continued fraction (and other related numbers) and comparing it against potential candidate bounds. From these experiments we aim to form precise conjectures, which will then be pursued theoretically with the goal of proving matching discrepancy estimates.

 Details: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TDeewPdmY3HxTNSNnBWqW1ugYvI_vfYa/view?usp=sharing
projects.goals: To experimentally verify and theoretically prove discrepancy bounds for Adler‚Äôs continued fraction and other known CF-normal numbers.
projects.tasks:
Read relevant literature including the works of Becher‚ÄìGraus, Vandehey, and Adler et al.

 Implement code to generate continued fractions and compute empirical discrepancy. Plot results and formulate conjectures.

 Theoretically prove the discrepancy bounds.
projects.requirements: Strong interest in theoretical computer science and mathematics. Programming skills are beneficial. Background in real analysis and probability is required.

projects.title_ru: Scaling efficient monosemantic experts in transformers with tensor decompositions
projects.annotation: Recently, Park et all. (https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.04139) has proposed to scale monosemanticity in MoE architectures by slicing FFT modules. However, the causal interpret ability of the network is still lacking. The project aims to extend the approach by creating a single shared tensor basis for all the experts in the Hierarchical tucker format and exploit new results in top-k attention gradient approximation (https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.04013) to make it scalable. Results of the project could benefit the development of more memory a efficient and interpretable MoE architectures.

Efficient Backpropagation Approach for Deep Models
projects.annotation: This project focuses on accelerating the backpropagation process for deep neural networks when training on large-scale datasets, while maintaining model performance. The study explores computational optimizations, such as gradient approximation, adaptive learning strategies, and parallelization techniques, to reduce training time and resource consumption. By improving the efficiency of backpropagation, the project aims to enable faster model training without compromising accuracy or generalization.
projects.goals: The goal of this project is to develop an efficient backpropagation approach that accelerates training of deep neural networks on large datasets while preserving model performance.
projects.tasks:
To analyze bottlenecks in standard backpropagation for deep learning models on large-scale data.

 To design and implement computationally efficient strategies for gradient computation and parameter updates.

 To evaluate the proposed approach on benchmark datasets and compare training speed and model performance with conventional methods.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge in Python, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning implementation
 - Enthusiastic to learn
 - Knowledge of English

projects.title_en: Designing a Standard Benchmark Dataset for Machine Learning and Deep Learning Evaluation
projects.annotation: This project aims to design a standardized benchmark dataset, for evaluating the performance of machine learning and deep learning models. The dataset will be carefully curated to cover diverse scenarios and challenges, enabling consistent and fair assessment of model accuracy, robustness, and generalization. By providing a widely usable benchmark, the project seeks to facilitate reproducible experimentation and support the development of more effective models across various tasks.
projects.goals: The goal of this project is to create a high-quality benchmark dataset that serves as a standard for evaluating and comparing machine learning and deep learning models.
projects.tasks:
To design and construct a dataset that includes diverse and representative samples suitable for ML and DL evaluation.

 To define clear data formats, labels, and preprocessing protocols to ensure reproducibility and usability.

 To validate the dataset by benchmarking several models and analyzing their performance to demonstrate their effectiveness.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge in Python, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning implementation
 - Enthusiastic to learn
 - Knowledge of English

projects.title_en: A novel metaheuristic approach for addressing generalized quadratic assignment problem
projects.annotation: The Generalized Quadratic Assignment Problem (GQAP) is a challenging combinatorial optimization problem with numerous real-world applications, including facility location, scheduling, and network design. Traditional optimization methods often struggle with the scalability and complexity of high-dimensional instances. This project aims to design and implement a novel evolutionary metaheuristic algorithm capable of efficiently solving large-scale GQAPs. The proposed approach will introduce innovative search strategies to enhance convergence speed and solution quality, while maintaining a balance between exploration and exploitation. Computational experiments will be conducted on benchmark instances, and the results will be compared against established algorithms from the literature to validate the effectiveness and competitiveness of the new method.
projects.goals: Designing new and efficient evolutionary algorithm
projects.tasks:
The objective of this project is to develop and evaluate a novel metaheuristic algorithm for efficiently solving the high-dimensional Generalized Quadratic Assignment Problem (GQAP). The project seeks to explore innovative evolutionary search mechanisms that can effectively balance exploration and exploitation, overcome local optima, and handle the scalability challenges inherent in GQAP.

 Through the design, implementation, and benchmarking of the proposed algorithm, the project aims to provide both theoretical and practical contributions to the field of combinatorial optimization.
projects.requirements:
- Programming in Python or MATLAB
 - Enthusiastic and ready to learn

projects.title_en: Adaptive Learning Based Genetic Engineering Algorithm for Combinatorial Optimization Problems
projects.annotation: This project focuses on the development of an Adaptive Learning-Based Genetic Engineering Algorithm (AL-GEA) for solving complex combinatorial optimization problems. Unlike traditional genetic algorithms, AL-GEA dynamically adjusts the application rates of its operators, such as crossover, mutation, directed mutation, and gene injection based on their performance in improving solution quality. This adaptive mechanism enhances both exploration and exploitation, leading to more robust and efficient search behavior. The proposed algorithm will be tested on benchmark combinatorial problems and compared with state-of-the-art metaheuristic approaches to demonstrate its effectiveness.
projects.goals: Designing a novel evolutionary approach based on adaptive learning
projects.tasks: The objective of this project is to design and implement an Adaptive Learning-Based Genetic Engineering Algorithm (AL-GEA) for efficiently solving combinatorial optimization problems. The project further aims to evaluate the algorithm‚Äôs performance against established metaheuristic methods to demonstrate its effectiveness and adaptability.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge in Python or MATLAB
 - Enthusiastic to learn
 - Knowledge in English

projects.title_en: Computationally Efficient Genetic Engineering Algorithm for Complex Optimization
projects.annotation: This project proposes a Computationally Efficient Genetic Engineering Algorithm (CE-GEA) for solving complex optimization problems. The algorithm is designed to leverage GPU acceleration and smart pattern extraction techniques to reduce computational cost while maintaining high solution quality significantly. By adaptively applying genetic operators in a data-driven manner, CE-GEA aims to achieve faster convergence and improved scalability compared to existing metaheuristics.
projects.goals: Design a computationally efficient Genetic Engineering Algorithm that leverages GPU acceleration and intelligent operator application to solve complex optimization problems with high speed and scalability.
projects.tasks: The objective of this project is to develop a fast and scalable Genetic Engineering Algorithm that efficiently solves complex optimization problems using GPU acceleration and smart operator application.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge in Python or MATLAB
 - Enthusiastic to learn
 - Knowledge in English

projects.title_en: Genetic Speciation Algorithm for Addressing Combinatorial Optimization Problems
projects.annotation: This project proposes a Genetic Speciation Algorithm for solving combinatorial optimization problems by leveraging clustering-based speciation techniques. By grouping similar individuals into species, the algorithm maintains diversity, prevents premature convergence, and enables more effective exploration of the solution space. The approach is designed to enhance algorithmic performance and scalability compared to traditional genetic algorithms, with results validated on benchmark optimization problems.
projects.goals: The goal of this project is to develop a Genetic Speciation Algorithm that leverages clustering-based speciation to enhance diversity and improve solution quality for combinatorial optimization problems.
projects.tasks: The objective of this project is to design a Genetic Speciation Algorithm that uses clustering to maintain population diversity and efficiently explore the solution space of combinatorial optimization problems.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge in Python or MATLAB
 - Enthusiastic to learn
 - Knowledge of English

projects.title_en: Student's Confusion Detection using EEG dataset
projects.annotation: This project focuses on detecting students‚Äô cognitive confusion using EEG signals recorded during learning tasks. The study aims to extract relevant features from EEG data and apply machine learning algorithms to classify confusion states. By analyzing neural patterns associated with cognitive load and uncertainty, the project seeks to develop an automated system that can support adaptive learning and personalized educational interventions.
projects.goals: The goal of this project is to develop an effective EEG-based system for detecting students‚Äô confusion.
projects.tasks:
To preprocess and analyze EEG datasets to identify features indicative of confusion.

 To design and train machine learning models capable of classifying confusion states accurately.

 To evaluate the performance of the models on benchmark datasets and assess their potential for real-time application in educational settings.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge in Python, Machine Learning and Deep Learning implementation
 - Enthusiastic to learn
 - Knowledge of English

projects.title_en: Emotional State Classification from Text Data Using Deep Learning Approaches
projects.annotation: This project aims to classify emotional states from textual data using deep learning techniques. By leveraging natural language processing and advanced neural network architectures, the study seeks to automatically identify emotions expressed in text. The project will explore different deep learning models and feature representations to improve classification accuracy and robustness, providing insights into automated emotion recognition from textual content.
projects.goals: The goal of this project is to develop an accurate and efficient deep learning-based system for classifying emotional states from text data.
projects.tasks:
To preprocess and represent textual data for deep learning applications.

 To design, implement, and compare different deep learning models for emotion classification.

 To evaluate the models‚Äô performance on benchmark datasets and analyze their effectiveness in recognizing diverse emotional states.
projects.requirements:
- Knowledge in Python, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning implementation
 - Enthusiastic to learn
 - Knowledge of English

projects.title_en: Reinforcement Learning for Accelerator Beamline Control: a simulation-based approach
projects.annotation: Particle accelerators play a pivotal role in advancing scientific research, yet optimizing beamline configurations to maximize particle transmission remains a labor-intensive task requiring expert intervention. In this work, we introduce RLABC (Reinforcement Learning for Accelerator Beamline Control), a Python-based library that reframes beamline optimization as a reinforcement learning (RL) problem. Leveraging the Elegant simulation framework, RLABC automates the creation of an RL environment from standard lattice and element input files, enabling sequential tuning of magnets to minimize particle losses. We define a comprehensive state representation capturing beam statistics, actions for adjusting magnet parameters, and a reward function focused on transmission efficiency. Employing the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm, we demonstrate RLABC's efficacy on two beamlines, achieving transmission rates of 94% and 91%, comparable to expert manual optimizations. This approach bridges accelerator physics and machine learning, offering a versatile tool for physicists and RL researchers alike to streamline beamline tuning.
projects.goals: Create an RL-based system to solve different beamline's architecures.
projects.tasks:
1- Our current approach works with several RL methodologies (DDPG is currently the best). We would like to check, if other approaches can give additional gain in performance or in training time. Generalization is also important, so that it is possible to train the agent on one accelerator configuration and not re-train (or at least fine-tune with a smaller number of examples). Try different RL algorithms with different hyperparameters, on our environment and examine their performance and generalization qualities to varying accelerator configurations.


2- One of the ideas to speed-up training and improve generalization is to train the agent in so-called stages, a sequence of changing environments. Essentially, the training starts with the simplest possible problem (small accelerator with several decision points) and gradually changes the environment to become more complex. Try several suggested stage-learning approaches and compare it to our baseline solutions in terms of final performance and generalization qualities.

Company information collecting system
Smart Landfill Monitoring and Garbage Classification System
projects.annotation:
The Smart Landfill Monitoring and Garbage Classification System is designed to
 modernize landfill operations through the use of artificial intelligence and computer
 vision.
 The solution integrates Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) and garbage type
 classification modules using YOLO??? and CNNs or ?????, and displays real-time data
 on a web-based dashboard. The system automates tracking of garbage trucks and

 categorization of waste to ensure transparency, environmental compliance, and data-
 driven landfill management. Results show ANPR accuracy above 95% and garbage

 classification accuracy above 85%, proving the feasibility of deploying AI-based
 automation in landfill operations.
 INTRODUCTION
 Traditional landfill monitoring lacks automation, relying on manual inspection, logbooks,
 and unverified data. This leads to inePiciencies and poor accountability. This project
 introduces a smart solution that leverages AI and computer vision to improve landfill
 transparency and operational control.
 RESEARCH BACKGROUND
 Computer vision has been increasingly applied to waste management, especially in
 smart city contexts. Existing studies focus on object detection and classification using
 CNNs and YOLO, but few systems integrate real-time ANPR with garbage classification in
 a landfill setting.
projects.goals: Smart Landfill Monitoring and Garbage Classification System
projects.tasks:
1- Orientation & Requirements Analysis
 ‚Ä¢ Understand the business objectives and system architecture.
 ‚Ä¢ Study functional requirements: ANPR, garbage classification, and dashboard.
 ‚Ä¢ Analysis open-source solution for ANPR , AI-based garbage classification and
 Dashboard
 2- Dataset Preparation & Environment Setup
 For ANPR Module
 ‚Ä¢ Research and Collect datasets from open sources plate (e.g., OpenALPR,
 Kaggle, UFPR-ALPR...).
 ‚Ä¢ Capture/collect custom license plate images.
 For Garbage Classification
 ‚Ä¢ Research and Collect datasets from open sources (e.g., TrashNet, TACO,
 Densely Annotated Garbage).
 ‚Ä¢ Organize data into categories: organic, plastic, glass, paper, metal, hazardous,
 construction...
 ‚Ä¢ Label images and augment the dataset for better training diversity.
 3- Environment Setup :
 ‚Ä¢ Set up Python environment: (Anaconda/venv), Python 3.9+, PyTorch?, Ultralytics
 YOLOv?...
 ‚Ä¢ Install libraries: TensorFlow, PyTorch, YOLOv, OpenCV, FastAPI, Pandas, etc.
 ‚Ä¢ Configure Jupyter Notebooks or VSCode.
 ‚Ä¢ ............
 4- ANPR Module
 ‚Ä¢ Use YOLOv or EasyOCR for license plate detection and recognition.
 ‚Ä¢ Train or fine-tune model on collected/augmented dataset.
 ‚Ä¢ Evaluate performance (precision, recall, F1-score).
 5- Garbage Classification Module
 ‚Ä¢ Use CNN or YOLOv or (for object classification) to detect garbage types in
 overhead images.
 ‚Ä¢ Train model with at least 7 categories.
 ‚Ä¢ Log misclassifications and retrain for improvements.
 ‚Ä¢ Evaluate performance (precision, recall, F1-score).
 6- Testing and Evaluation
 ‚Ä¢ Perform model testing on new unseen data.
 ‚Ä¢ Evaluate ANPR (aim: >95% accuracy) and Garbage Classification (aim: >85%
 accuracy).
 ‚Ä¢ Analyze confusion matrix for garbage classification errors.
 ‚Ä¢ Document accuracy, issues, and recommendations.
 7- User Dashboard Development

 5
 ‚Ä¢ Create wireframes (Figma) for the dashboard (real-time logs, garbage type, truck
 tracking).
 ‚Ä¢ Develop MVP
 ‚Ä¢ Develop front end using React.js or HTML/Bootstrap.
 ‚Ä¢ Backend with FastAPI or Django REST.
 ‚Ä¢ Connect with database for displaying truck logs and garbage classification
 results.
 ‚Ä¢ Implement role-based access (admin/operator/inspector).
 8- Integration and Final Testing
 ‚Ä¢ Integrate ANPR and Garbage Classification modules with dashboard.
 ‚Ä¢ Simulate data flow: Entry ‚Üí Detection ‚Üí Classification ‚Üí Dashboard update.
 ‚Ä¢ Create test logs and mock dump event scenarios.
 9- Documentation & Final Presentation
 ‚Ä¢ Document model training, datasets, architecture, and accuracy results.
 ‚Ä¢ Create user manual for dashboard usage.
 ‚Ä¢ Prepare a final presentation for stakeholders (with demo).
 ‚Ä¢ Submit internship report.

projects.title_en: Improved optimization of LogSumExp and its applications in ML
projects.annotation: The LogSumExp function plays a central role in many important optimization problems from machine learning, optimal transport, distributionally robust optimization and other applications. When the number of exponential terms inside the logarithm is large or infinite, existing optimization approaches suffer from numerical instabilities and other issues. Recently, a new approach to optimizing LogSumExp has been proposed, see https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.24894. The project consist in choosing an application area and comparing the approach to the baseline. For more details, see the project description in https://disk.yandex.ru/i/xcIDF79xM3MRPg.
